questions.text: A 5-year-old child presented with complaints of knee pain and delayed development. He was advised to undergo a knee x-ray, which is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given x-ray shows fraying and splaying of the distal ends of the tibia and fibula.
  • This is seen in rickets in children.
  • The radiographic features include:
    • fraying:indistinct margins of the metaphysis
    • splaying: widening of metaphyseal ends.
    • Cupping:concavity of metaphysis
  • Rickets:fraying, cupping, splaying and widening of epiphysis are the characteristic features seen in the X-ray of rickets patients.
  • But the earliest sign is loss of the provisional zone of calcification.
  • Healing rickets shows a white line of healing.
  • The above features are prominent at the growth plates where growth is greatest:
    • Knee: distal femur, proximal tibia
    • Wrist: especially the ulna
    • Anterior rib ends: rachitic rosary

Explanation of other options:

Scurvy (Option B) shows the radiographic features of Wimberger's ring sign, Pelkan spur, Frankel line and Trummerfeld zone, not the fraying, cupping and splaying.

Osteogenesis imperfecta (Option C) shows the features of multiple diaphyseal fractures after a minor trauma, not the fraying, cupping and splaying.

Congenital syphilis (Option D): Congenital syphilis can lead to various bone abnormalities, including sabre shins (anteriorly curved tibia) and other skeletal deformities, and it will not show fraying, cupping and splaying.

Key Takeaways:

  • Always consider rickets in a child with bony deformities and delayed milestones.
  • Metaphyseal changes on radiographs are diagnostic.
  • Radiographs of the knee and wrist re crucial for early diagnosis.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presented with bleeding gums and swollen knee joints. He underwent a knee x-ray, which is shown below. Identify the marked finding used to diagnose the condition.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given x-ray shows a radio-opaque line known as Frenkel's line, along with the history of bleeding gums in a child will help in diagnosing it as a case of scurvy.
  • Radiographic features of scurvy
    • Generalized osteopenia
    • Cortical thinning: "pencil-point" cortex
    • Periosteal reaction due to subperiosteal haemorrhage
    • Scorbutic rosary: expansion of the costochondral junctions
    • May relate to the fracturing of the zone of provisional calcification during normal respiration
    • Similar to the rachitic rosary appearance as seen in rickets
    • Hemarthrosis
    • Wimberger's ring sign: circular, opaque radiologic shadow surrounding epiphyseal centres of ossification, which may result from bleeding
    • Frankel line: dense zone of provisional calcification
    • Trummerfeld zone: lucent metaphyseal band underlying Frankel line
    • Pelkan spur: metaphyseal spurs that result in cupping of the metaphysis
    • Pelkan fracture: metaphyseal corner fracture

Explanation of other options:

Looser's zones (Option B) also known as pseudofractures, can be characteristically seen in osteomalacia.

Fraying of metaphyses (Option C): Classically seen in rickets, not in scurvy.

Cupping of epiphyses (Option D): Another hallmark of rickets is softening and deformation of the metaphyseal ends.

questions.text: Given is an X-ray of a child who has a history of getting fractures from minor injuries with blue sclera. What is the diagnosis based on the radiographic feature and the history given?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The radiograph shows the multiple diaphyseal fractures in different stages of healing after a minor trauma, and is associated with blue sclera points towards the diagnosis of Osteogenesis imperfecta.
  • Osteogenesis imperfecta (OI) refers to a heterogeneous group of congenital, non-sex-linked, genetic disorders of collagen type I production, involving connective tissues and bones.
  • The hallmark feature of osteogenesis imperfecta is osteoporosis and fragile bones that fracture easily, as well as blue sclera, dental fragility and hearing loss.

X-ray image of a child with Osteogenesis imperfecta.

The radiographic features are as follows:

  • Head, neck and spine
    • basilar invagination
    • wormian bones
    • kyphoscoliosis
    • vertebral compression fractures
    • codfish vertebrae
    • platyspondyly
  • Chest
    • pectus excavatum or carinatum
    • accordion ribs
  • Pelvis
    • protrusion acetabuli
    • coxa vara
  • General
    • severe osteoporosis

Explanation of other options:

Osteomalacia (Option B): Seen in adults, not children. Presents with pseudofractures (Looser's zones) and bone pain, without blue sclera.

Osteoporosis (Option C) is characterized by a reduction in bone mass and deterioration of bone microarchitecture, leading to increased bone fragility and a higher risk of fractures. It is diagnosed when the bone mineral density (BMD) T-score is less than -2.5 standard deviations below the young adult mean, as measured by dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DEXA). Osteoporosis is commonly seen in postmenopausal women due to estrogen deficiency.

Rickets (Option D) refers to deficient mineralisation of the growth plate in the pediatric population. It occurs due to inadequate vitamin D, calcium, or phosphate levels. Radiographically, rickets is associated with specific bone changes. These include: Fraying, Splaying, Cupping and Pseudofractures.

questions.text: A middle-aged female presents with severe bone pain at multiple sites. Plain radiographs reveal multiple lytic lesions in the pelvis, ribs and femur, fracture of the clavicles and subperiosteal reabsorption of metacarpals over the radial aspect. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The most likely diagnosis for a middle-aged female presenting with severe bone pains at multiple sites, along with plain radiographs revealing multiple lytic lesions in the pelvis, ribs, and femur, fractures of the clavicles, and subperiosteal reabsorption of the metacarpals over the radial aspect, is hyperparathyroidism.
  • This condition is characterised by excessive secretion of parathyroid hormone (PTH), which leads to increased bone resorption.
  • The radiographic findings of multiple lytic lesions (brown tumours, subperiosteal bone resorption (especially on the radial aspects of the metacarpals), and pathological fractures are classic features of severe hyperparathyroidism.
  • Subperiosteal erosion- hallmark feature of hyperparathyroidism, best seen on the radial aspect of the middle phalanx of the 2nd and 3rd fingers.
  • Other featuresof hyperparathyroidism- loss of lamina dura of teeth, pepper pot skull or salt and pepper skull, pathological fractures.

Explanation of other options:

Hyperthyroidism (Option A) causes increased metabolism in the body, whereas it is not associated with any typical bone changes.

Renal osteodystrophy (Option C) occurs as a result of chronic kidney disease. It leads to secondary hyperparathyroidism, which shows the 'Rugger Jersey Spine' appearance is characteristic of this condition.

Osteomalacia (Option D) shows the presence of 'Looser's zones, aka pseudofractures, on X-ray.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child has been brought to the hospital with complaints of discomfort in the hip joint, limping while walking and decreased range of motion in the hip. The following radiograph was taken. What will be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given pelvic radiograph shows: Increased joint space in the right hip, Irregularity and flattening of the femoral head epiphysis. Signs suggestive of avascular necrosis of the femoral head, mostly duee to Perthes disease.
  • Perthes disease is idiopathic avascular necrosis of the femoral head in children, most commonly seen in boys aged 4-8 years.
  • The clinical presentation includes limping gait, hip or knee pain, and restricted internal rotation and abduction of the hip.
  • The radiograph typically shows:
    • Increased joint space
    • Flattening, sclerosis, and fragmentation of the femoral head epiphysis
    • Widening of the metaphysis (early stage)

Explanation of other options:

Slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE) (Option A): This condition usually occurs in older children and adolescents (typically between 10 and 16 years old). It involves a displacement of the femoral head relative to the femoral neck. Radiographs show a slip of the epiphysis, often described as "ice cream slipping off the cone."

Myositis ossificans (Option C): This condition involves the formation of bone tissue inside muscle or soft tissues following trauma. It is unlikely to present primarily with hip joint discomfort, limping, and decreased range of motion without a preceding history of trauma.

Meyer's dysplasia (Option D): This is a rare condition and typically presents with developmental abnormalities of the epiphyses. It does not usually present with acute symptoms like hip pain and limping.

questions.text: "Champagne Glass" pelvis is seen in?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Achondroplasiais a genetic disorder characterised by short stature and abnormal bone growth, including a relatively narrow and flattened pelvis, which resembles the shape of a Champagne Glass on X-ray.
  • It is the most common cause of disproportionate short stature.

Deformities ;

  • Brachydactyly
  • Starfish hand
  • Trident hand
  • Frontal bossing of the skull
  • Saddle nose
  • Champagne glass pelvis
  • Bullet nose vertebra

Congenital hypothyroidism (CHT) (Option B), previously known as cretinism, can be of thyroidal or central (hypothalamic/pituitary) origin and can have a widely diverse molecular aetiology. Radiologically, it shows delayed skeletal maturation and cortical thickening.

Mucopolysaccharidosis (Option C): This group of lysosomal storage disorders leads to the accumulation of glycosaminoglycans, resulting in skeletal abnormalities like dysostosis multiplex. The radiological findings in mucopolysaccharidoses include thickened, irregular vertebrae.

Acromegaly (Option D): This condition results from excessive growth hormone production, leading to enlarged bones and soft tissues. Radiological findings include enlarged sella turcica, thickened calvarium, and widened joints.

questions.text: Which abnormality is represented in the radiological image given below?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The radiograph shows anterior displacement of one vertebral body over the one below it (Beheaded Scottish dog appearance), consistent with spondylolisthesis.
  • Most commonly affects the L4-L5 or L5-S1
  • The cause can be degenerative, isthmic (pars interarticularis defect), traumatic, or dysplastic.
  • Lateral radiographs demonstrate the slip, which is often graded using Meyerding classification (Grade I to V based on % of slip).
  • In contrast to spondylolysis (defect in pars), this condition involves actual vertebral slippage.
  • The Scottie dog sign refers to the normal appearance of the lumbar spine when seen on oblique radiographic projection.

Explanation of other options:

Disc herniation (Option A): Protrusion or extrusion of intervertebral disc material without vertebral displacement

Spondylosis (Option B): Scotty dog with collar is seen in spondylolysis, whereas the given X-ray shows a beheaded Scottish dog appearance, suggestive of Spondylolisthesis.

Spondyloptosis(Option D) is a rare and refers to a slippage of the L5 vertebra in which the entire vertebral body of L5 is located below the top of S1. It is the most severe degree of slippage possible.

Note:

questions.text: 33-year-old male patient complains of backache and difficulty in bending forward, presenting with the following X-ray findings. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given Radiograph shows linear calcification of the interspinous ligament known as the Dagger Sign, seen in Ankylosing spondylitis.
  • Ankylosing spondylitis( Bechterew disease or Marie Strumpell disease) is a seronegative spondyloarthropathy, which results in fusion (ankylosis) of the spine and sacroiliac (SI) joints.
  • The clinical features include backache, uveitis, heel pain and restricted lumbar flexion (Schober test)

Other radiological features include;

  • Bamboo Spine
  • Trolley Track Sign
  • Romanus Lesions

Explanation of other options:

Osteoporosis (Option A) is characterized by a reduction in bone mass and deterioration of bone microarchitecture, leading to increased bone fragility and a higher risk of fractures. It is diagnosed when the bone mineral density (BMD) T-score is less than -2.5 standard deviations below the young adult mean, as measured by dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DEXA). Osteoporosis is commonly seen in postmenopausal women due to estrogen deficiency.

Paget's disease (Option C): This is a disorder that involves abnormal bone remodelling, where the normal bone tissue is replaced with structurally abnormal bone, which shows a cotton wool appearance on skull X-ray.

Osteopetrosis (Option D) is characterised by abnormally dense bones due to defective osteoclast function, leading to impaired bone resorption. This results in bones that are brittle and prone to fracture despite their increased density. The 'bone within bone' appearance is a result of impaired bone remodelling.

questions.text: A pediatric patient underwent radiographic evaluation for suspected skeletal abnormalities. The x-ray image below shows metaphyseal widening with an Erlenmeyer flask deformity (flaring of the metaphysis). Based on the radiological findings, which of the following conditions can present with this appearance?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The Erlenmeyer flask deformity in bones,particularly the long bones, is a radiological finding associated with certain genetic and metabolic conditions, such as:
    • Thalassemia (Option B ruled out): Chronic marrow hyperplasia causes expansion of the medullary space, giving rise to the Erlenmeyer flask appearance.
    • Osteopetrosis (Option A ruled out): A bone remodeling disorder leading to dense but brittle bones with metaphyseal flaring.
    • Craniometaphyseal dysplasia (Option C ruled out): Rare genetic condition causing metaphyseal flaring.
  • These conditions lead to abnormal bone development and increased bone marrow activity, causing the characteristic flask-shaped widening of the metaphysis seenin radiological images.

Key Takeaways:

Mnemonics for Erlenmeyer Flask Deformity

CHONG

C: craniometaphyseal dysplasias/Pyle's'sdisease

H: haemoglobinopathies (thalassemia, sickle cell disease)

O: osteopetrosis

N: Niemann-Pick disease

G: Gaucher disease

questions.text: Identify the muscle marked in the given image
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given image shows an MRI of the shoulder joint.
  • The structure marked in the image is Supraspinatus
  • The supraspinatus muscle is one of the four rotator cuff muscles.
  • It originates from the supraspinous fossa of the scapula and inserts into the superior facet of the greater tubercle of the humerus.
  • It is best visualised on coronal or sagittal MRI sequences as the most superior muscle crossing the shoulder joint.
  • The muscle is commonly involved in rotator cuff tears and is evaluated in shoulder pain cases.

Explanation of other options:

Infraspinatus (Option B) is on the inferior aspect of the scapular spine and is inserted into the greater tuberosity of the humerus.

Deltoid muscle (Option C) will insert into the deltoid tuberosity and is on the lateral aspect of the humerus.

Biceps tendon (Option D) takes its origin from the tip of the coracoid process and supraglenoid tubercle of the scapula.

questions.text: A patient had a history of seizures, following which he had difficulty moving the upper limb. He underwent an X-ray, which is shown below. Identify the likely diagnosis based on the given shoulder radiograph.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given X-ray image shows the head of the humerus, which is internally rotated such that it gives a light bulb appearance. This is seen in posterior dislocation.
  • It occurs most commonly during a convulsion or after an electric shock. It can also happen after a fall on the flexed, adducted arm, either by a direct blow to the front of the shoulder or due to a fall on the outstretched hand.

Radiological signs described in posterior dislocation of the shoulder in the AP:

  • Light bulb sign- Shape of humeral head appears like that of an electric bulb
  • Rim sign- Widening of the glenohumeral joint space > 6 mm
  • Vacant glenoid sign. The Glenoid fossa looks empty as the humeral head has moved away from it.
  • Trough sign- Vertical line seen on the anteromedial part of the humeral head due to the impression fracture by the glenoid labrum

Explanation of other options:

Anterior shoulder dislocation (Option A) is by far the commonest type of dislocation and usually results from forced abduction, external rotation and extension

Inferior shoulder dislocation (Option C) is the least common form of shoulder dislocation. The condition is also called luxatio erecta because the arm appears to be permanently held upward, in fixed abduction. The patient will often present with their hand placed on the head or near it.

Superior subluxation (Option D) is seen in rotator cuff arthropathy or massive rotator cuff tears. The humeral head migrates superiorly due to loss of rotator cuff support.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient on long-term steroid therapy presents with the recent onset of severe pain in the right hip. The imaging modality of choice for this problem is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • MRI is considered as IOC for evaluating avascular necrosis, particularly in patients onlong-term steroid therapy who are at increased risk for developing this condition.
  • MRI provides excellent soft tissue contrast and is highly sensitive for detecting early signs of AVN, including bone marrow oedema and necrosis.

Common sites of AVN are:

  • Head of the femur in fracture neck of femur and posterior dislocation of the hip
  • The body of the talus is fractured through the neck of the talus
  • Proximal pole of the scaphoid in a fracture through the waist of the scaphoid
  • Head of the humerus
  • The capitulum

The radiographic appearance of avascular necrosis of the femoral head may show the following changes:

  • Sclerosis of the femoral head
  • Flattening or loss of sphericity of the femoral head
  • Crescent sign: Subchondral fracture overlying the necrotic segment of the femoral head
  • In severe stages, it may show femoral head collapse and arthritic changes in the joint.

Explanation of other options:

CT scan (Option A): CT scan helps detect bony changes and sclerosis, but is less sensitive in early disease stages.

Bone scan (Option B): Bone scan can detect avascular necrosis, but lacks specificity and may miss very early lesions.

Plain X-ray (Option D): X-rays may appear normal in the early stages and are not reliable for early detection.

questions.text: A child presents with fever, pain and swelling in the leg. The following X-ray was taken. What is the diagnosis based on the radiograph?
questions.solution:
Explanation:
  • The 'onion peel' appearance on a radiograph shown above is typically associated with Ewing's sarcoma.
  • Ewing's sarcoma is a primary malignant bone tumour commonly seen in children and adolescents.
  • It often presents with fever, pain, swelling, and systemic symptoms resembling infection.
  • Radiographically, it shows a permeative pattern of bone destruction with an "onion-skin" periosteal reaction, which is visible in the X-ray shown.
  • Commonly affects long bones, pelvis, and ribs.
  • This appearance refers to theconcentric layers of new bone formation seen around the periosteum of the affected bone, resembling the layers of an onion peel.
  • This characteristic finding is due to the aggressive periosteal reaction often seen in Ewing's sarcoma.

Explanation of other options;

Giant Cell Tumour (Option A): This tumour typically appears as a well-defined radiolucent lesion with a thin sclerotic rim. It often presents with a 'soap bubble' appearance on radiographs due to the presence of numerous osteoclast-like giant cells within the tumour.

Osteogenic Sarcoma (Osteosarcoma) (Option C): Osteogenic sarcoma typically presents as a destructive lesion with variable amounts of mineralisation. On radiographs, it often appears as a mixed lytic and sclerotic lesion with areas of Codman's triangle (reactive bone formation at the tumour margin)

Multiple Myeloma (Option D): Multiple myeloma is characterised by multiple lytic lesions throughout the skeletal system. These lesions appear as well-defined radiolucent areas with no sclerotic rim.

questions.text: A patient presents with a bone lesion, and the radiograph reveals a characteristic "soap bubble" appearance. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Osteoclastoma (Giant Cell Tumour)- shows soap bubble appearance.
  • Also known as Giant Cell Tumour (GCT), it is a benign but locally aggressive tumour.
  • Typically occurs in skeletally mature individuals (20-40 years).
  • Radiologically presents as a well-defined, eccentric lytic lesion in the epiphyseal region.
  • Characteristic 'soap bubble appearance' due to internal septations.
  • No matrix mineralisation and often extends to subarticular bone.

Explanation of other options:

Osteoid osteoma shows (Option A): Radiographic appearance, typically presents as a small, well-circumscribed radiolucent nidus surrounded by dense sclerotic bone. It does not have a 'soap bubble' appearance.

Osteochondroma (Option B) shows the radiographic appearance as a bony outgrowth (exostosis) capped by cartilage. It is usually a pedunculated or sessile lesion projecting from the bone surface.

Osteogenic sarcoma (Osteosarcoma) (Option D): Typically presents as a mixed lytic and sclerotic lesion with sunburst pattern due to aggressive periosteal reaction and Codman's triangle.

questions.text: The Best radiological view for the diagnosis of scaphoid fracture is?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The best radiological view for the diagnosis of a scaphoid fractureis the oblique view.
  • This view is often the most effective for diagnosing scaphoid fractures.
  • It provides a clear image of the scaphoid bone with minimal overlap of other carpal bones, making it easier to identify fractures.

The scaphoid fracture is best seen in the oblique view or PA view with 15° ulnar.

Explanation of other options:

Anteroposterior (Option A): AP view is a basic view but may not show subtle fractures of the scaphoid due to overlapping carpal bones.

Lateral (Option B): Lateral view is used to assess carpal alignment and dislocations, but is less useful for detecting scaphoid fractures.

Posteroanterior (Option D): PA view is standard, but again may miss scaphoid fractures hidden by bone superimposition.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with sensorineural deafness and bony abnormality in the left leg has serum calcium-9.5 and alkaline phosphate 440 IU/l skeletal survey shows the following skull appearance, most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Based on the clinical presentation and radiographic findings described, the most probable diagnosis is Paget's disease.

  • Paget's diseaseof bone is a chronic disorder characterised by abnormal bone remodelling, resulting in enlarged and deformed bones. It can affect one or multiple bones.
  • Sensorineural deafnesscan occur in Paget's disease due to compression of cranial nerves, particularly the auditory nerve, by enlarged bones of the skull base.
  • Elevated alkaline phosphatase levels are characteristic of Paget's disease due toincreased bone turnover.
  • Radiographic findings ofivory vertebrae (dense, sclerotic appearance of the vertebrae) and cotton-wool spots (areas of sclerosis) on the skull are classic features of Paget's disease.

The lesions seen are:

  • Osteoporosis circumscripta: large, well-defined lytic lesion
  • Cotton wool appearance: mixed lytic and sclerotic lesions of the skull
  • Diploic widening:both inner and outer calvarial tables are involved, with the former usually more extensively affected
  • Tam o'Shanter sign: frontal bone enlargement, with the appearance of the skull falling over the facial bones, like a Tam o' Shanter hat.

Explanation of other options :

Osteosclerotic metastasis (Option B) typically present as focal areas of increased bone density on imaging studies, often associated with a history of breast, prostate, or lung cancer. But the overall clinical presentation and radiographic findings described are more consistent with Paget's disease.

Osteoporosis (Optin C) is due to the low bone mineral density and deterioration of bone tissue, leading to an increased risk of fractures. It typically does not cause bony enlargement or deformity as seen in the case described.

Fibrous dysplasia (Option D) is a bone disorder where fibrous tissue replaces normal bone, leading to weakened and expanded areas of bone. However, sensorineural deafness and ivory vertebrae are not typical features of fibrous dysplasia.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female with chronic back pain. A radiograph of the lumbar spine was performed. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • As the above radiographs show decreased bone density and cortical thickness, and vertebra-like cord fish, along with the patient having back pain, which is suggestive of osteoporosis.
  • The X-ray shows multiple vertebral body fractures with anterior wedging and loss of vertebral height, classic for osteoporotic compression fractures.
  • Osteoporosis leads to decreased bone mineral density, making bones fragile and susceptible to compression fractures, especially in the thoracolumbar region.

Explanation of other options:

Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) (Option B) is a chronic autoimmune, multisystemic inflammatory disease that affects organs and the synovial tissues, and joints. The cervical spine is frequently involved in rheumatoid arthritis and shows atlantoaxial subluxation.

Renal osteodystrophy (Option C) occurs as a result of chronic kidney disease. It leads to secondary hyperparathyroidism, which shows the 'Rugger Jersey Spine' appearance is characteristic of this condition.

Paget's disease (Option D): This is a disorder that involves abnormal bone remodelling, where the normal bone tissue is replaced with structurally abnormal bone, which shows a cotton wool appearance on skull X-ray.

questions.text: The gold standard for the diagnosis of osteoporosis is?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The gold standardfor the diagnosis of osteoporosis is Dual energy X-ray absorptiometry (DEXA or DXA).
  • Dual energy X-ray absorptiometry (DEXA or DXA): This is the most widely used and recognised method for measuring bone mineral density (BMD).
  • It is considered the gold standard because it is highly accurate, has low radiation exposure, and can measure BMD at both the hip and spine, which are critical sites for assessing fracture risk in osteoporosis.
  • The World Health Organisation (WHO) operationally defines osteoporosis when the bone mineral density (BMD) T-score is less than -2.5 standard deviations below the young adult mean, as measured by dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DEXA). Osteoporosis is commonly seen in postmenopausal women due to estrogen deficiency.
  • Vertebral osteoporosis manifests asa codfish/fish mouth vertebra.

Explanation of other options:
Single energy X-ray absorptiometry (Option B): Less accurate and not commonly used in modern practice.

Ultrasonography (Option C): Used for screening but not diagnostic; lacks precision and reproducibility.

Quantitative computed tomography (QCT) (Option D): Can measure BMD, but has higher radiation and is not standard for routine use.

questions.text: Stryker's view is used in the shoulder joint to visualise?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Recurrent subluxation is one of the primary uses ofStryker's view, as it helps in assessing the position and stability of the shoulder joint.
  • Stryker's viewis used for Hill-Sach's lesion in recurrent anterior subluxation of the shoulder joint.

BEST X-RAY VIEWS ;

  • Pneumoperitoneum or hollow viscus perforation → CXR erect
  • Pneumothorax → Expiratory film
  • Pleural effusion → Ipsilateral lateral decubitus view
  • Patella fracture → Skyline view
  • Acetabular fracture → Judet view
  • CTEV → KITE View
  • CXR erect ( PA view) → Mc radiograph full inspiration; arms abducted; erect
  • CXR (AP VIEW) → Trauma with lower limb fractures/ ICU patients
  • Expiratory film → Pneumothorax and foreign body

Explanation of other options:

Muscle calcification (Option A): Better visualised with soft tissue imaging or AP shoulder views.

Subacromial calcification (Option C): Best seen in Neer's view or supraspinatus outlet view.

Bicipital groove (Option D): Best evaluated using the Fisk view or axial imaging modalities.

questions.text: Calcification of meniscal cartilage is a feature of?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Pseudogoutis a condition characterised by the deposition of calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate crystals in the joints, leading to inflammation, pain, and swelling.
  • When these crystals deposit in the meniscal cartilageof the knee joint, they can cause calcification of the meniscal cartilage.
  • This calcification can be visualised on radiographic imaging, such as X-rays.

Explanation of other options:

Acromegaly (Option A) is due to increased growth hormone production, often resulting in enlargement of bones and soft tissues. Acromegaly can lead to joint problems such as osteoarthritis due to the increased stress on the joints.

Hyperparathyroidism (Option B) is a condition characterised by excessive secretion of parathyroid hormone (PTH), which can lead to hypercalcemia and subsequent deposition of calcium in soft tissues and organs. Hyperparathyroidism can cause soft tissue calcifications in various locations, including blood vessels and kidneys.

Reiter's syndrome (Option C) also known as reactive arthritis, is a type of inflammatory arthritis that typically develops in response to an infection elsewhere in the body, such as a urinary tract infection or gastrointestinal infection. It is characterised by joint pain, swelling, and inflammation, often affecting the joints of the lower extremities and the axial skeleton.

questions.text: Geographic lytic lesions in the vault of the skull with bevelled edges are seen with?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Geographic lytic lesions in the skull with bevelled edgesare typically associated with eosinophilic granuloma, also known as Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH).
  • Eosinophilic granuloma is a rare disorder characterised by the proliferation of Langerhans cells, which are a type of immune cell, and it can affect various organs, including the bones.

The radiographic features involving the skull are

  • Solitary or multiple punched-out lytic lesions
  • Double contour or bevelled edge appearance may be seen due to asymmetrical involvement of the inner and outer tables (hole within a hole) sign.
  • Button sequestrum representing residual bone.
  • Geographic skull

Explanation of other options:

Multiple Myeloma (Option B) is a malignant neoplasm of plasma cells that often leads to osteolytic lesions. These lesions appear as multiple 'punched out' radiolucent areas on radiographs, especially visible in the skull.

Hyperparathyroidism (Option C) is characterised by excessive secretion of parathyroid hormone (PTH), which leads to increased bone resorption. The radiographic findings of multiple lytic lesions (brown tumours), subperiosteal bone resorption (especially on the radial aspects of the metacarpals), and pathological fractures are classic features of severe hyperparathyroidism.

Thalassemia (Option D) can cause bone changes due to marrow hyperplasia, leading to a 'hair on end' appearance on skull radiographs.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is least likely to present as an acentric osteolytic lesion?
questions.solution:
Explanation:
  • The condition least likely to present as an eccentric osteolytic lesion is a Simple bone cyst.
  • Simple bone cysts are typically central, located in the metaphysis of long bones such as the proximal humerus and femur.
  • These lesions are centrally located within the medullary cavity and have thin sclerotic margins.
  • In contrast, aneurysmal bone cysts, fibrous cortical defects, and giant cell tumours usually show eccentric lytic patterns on imaging.

The condition least likely to present as an eccentric osteolytic lesion is a Simple bone cyst.

Simple bone cyst (Unicameral bone cyst): Typically presents as a central, not eccentric, osteolytic lesion. It usually occurs in the metaphysis of long bones, such as the proximal humerus or femur, and is often discovered incidentally or following a pathological fracture.

Explanation of other options:

Aneurysmal bone cyst (Option A): Typically presents as an eccentric, expansile, and osteolytic lesion. These are often found in the metaphysis of long bones and can cause significant bone expansion.

Giant cell tumour (Option B): Usually arises in the epiphysis of long bones and presents as an eccentric, osteolytic lesion. It is known for causing bone destruction and expansion.

Fibrous cortical defect (Option C): Also known as non-ossifying fibroma, it commonly presents as an eccentric, osteolytic lesion located in the cortex of long bones in children and adolescents.

choices.text: Fracture of the tibia and fibula

questions.text: A 15-year-old patient had a history of falling, after which he had pain around the ankle joint. He underwent an X-ray ankle, which is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The radiograph shows an eccentric, expansile, lytic lesion with thin sclerotic margins involving the distal metaphysis of the tibia, suggestive of an aneurysmal bone cyst.
  • ABCs are benign, blood-filled, expansile lesions commonly seen in adolescents and young adults.
  • They frequently involve the metaphysis of long bones and the spine.
  • Radiographically, they appear as eccentric, expansile lytic lesions with a "soap bubble" appearance and may cause cortical thinning or expansion.

Explanation of other options:

Simple bone cyst (Unicameral bone cyst) (Option A): Typically presents as a central, not eccentric, osteolytic lesion. It usually occurs in the metaphysis of long bones, such as the proximal humerus or femur, and is often discovered incidentally or following a pathological fracture.

Fracture of tibia and fibula (Option C) shows the defect in the cortex of the bone, whereas X-ray shows multilocular lesions in the metaphysis.

Giant Cell Tumour (Option D): This tumour typically appears as a well-defined radiolucent lesion with a thin sclerotic rim. It often presents with a 'soap bubble' appearance on radiographs due to the presence of numerous osteoclast-like giant cells within the tumour in a mature skeleton.

questions.text: In radionuclide imaging, which of the following is the most useful radiopharmaceutical for skeletal imaging?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Radioisotope used for bone scintigraphy is 99mTc-polyphosphate compounds[m/c -Tc- MDP (methylene diphosphonate)]
  • The most useful radiopharmaceutical for skeletal imaging in radionuclide imaging isTechnetium-99m linked to Methylene diphosphonate (99mTc-MDP).
  • It is taken up by bone in proportion to blood flow and osteoblastic activity, making it highly sensitive for detecting changes in bone metabolism such as bone tumours, fractures, infections, or metastases.

Image of Bone Scan

Explanation of other options:

Gallium-67 scan (Option A): Used primarily for imaging of inflammatory processes, infections, and certain tumors such as lymphoma. It is not ideal for skeletal imaging.

Tc-99m sulphur colloid scan (Option B) is used to differentiate Focal Nodular Hyperplasia can be differentiated from fibrolamellar HCC, FNH shows hot uptake on the scan due to the presence of macrophages and reticulocytes, which are not seen in fibrolamellar HCC.

DOPA-PET (Option C) is used for assessment of extra-abdominal pheochromocytoma.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • On radiograph, it typically shows a "corduroy" or "jail bar" appearance due to vertically oriented thickened trabeculae , seen in vertebral hemangioma.
  • Vertebral hemangioma is a benign vascular lesion of the spine and is the most common benign spinal neoplasm.
  • CT may show a "polka-dot" appearance on axial images.
  • Most cases are asymptomatic and discovered incidentally, although they may rarely cause cord compression.

Explanation of other options:

Osteopetrosis (Option B) is characterised by abnormally dense bones due to defective osteoclast function, leading to impaired bone resorption. This results in bones that are brittle and prone to fracture despite their increased density. The 'bone within bone' appearance is a result of impaired bone remodelling.

Tuberculosis of the spine (Pott's disease) (Option C) is characterised by a large paravertebral abscess, marked collapse of the vertebra and decreased joint space.

Multiple Myeloma (Option D) is a malignant neoplasm of plasma cells that often leads to osteolytic lesions. These lesions appear as multiple 'punched out' radiolucent areas on radiographs, especially visible in the skull.
